video.title: Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
I wonder if there&#39;s a designer at Ryu Ga Gotoku 
Studio who desperately wants to be creating

something other than Yakuza games—i.e., sandbox 
crime dramas about well-dressed Japanese kung

fu mobsters that vacillate between sincerity 
and pisstake on a moment-to-moment basis—and

who is slowly going out of their sodding mind. 
Possibly the person who brought us Yakuza Dead

Souls and Judgment because they wanted to do a 
zombie game and a private eye noir, respectively,

and who recently must have gone, &quot;Gosh, I&#39;d love 
to make a pirate game about epic sea battles and

crew management and swordfights with lots of hairy 
men named Roger.&quot; After which some higher-up said,

&quot;Great idea, but remember to put in a whole bunch 
of well-dressed Japanese kung fu mobsters. And

make it about Goro Majima—he wears an eyepatch; 
that&#39;s 90% of the way there already.&quot; &quot;What,

in pirate times?&quot; &quot;No, fair enough. Tell 
you what, set it in the present day. But

still with old-style pirates because if you 
make it about Somalian people traffickers,

it&#39;s gonna depress everyone. Yes, that all 
makes perfect sense; bing bang toodly splat. Oh,

and set it in Hawaii so we can literally 
copy-paste the whole Honolulu map from

Infinite Wealth and bolt it onto the 
side like a malformed conjoined twin.&quot;

I guess you can&#39;t fault them for being economical, 
but Pirate Yakuza gives me Assassin&#39;s Creed: Flack

Blag bashflacks—I mean Black Flag flashbacks—in 
the way I really liked it when it was being a

pirate game and liked it a lot less when it went 
back to being a Yakuza game. The setup is noted

eyepatch-wearing bastard Goro Majima wakes up on 
a desert island with no memory and is immediately

accosted by burly toughs, whereupon he goes, 
&quot;Hang on! Protagonist-grade amnesia? Random

burly toughs showing up with an inadequately 
established beef? It&#39;s finally happened! I&#39;m

the main character of a Yakuza game again!&quot; And 
then he lathers the fucking shite out of them,

dusts his hands, and goes, &quot;Right, now all I 
need is the token helpless, innocent character

whose desires and wellbeing will inexplicably be 
my central, driving motivation.&quot; Looks around,

points to the first small, asthmatic boy he 
sees. &quot;You! You&#39;ll do! I&#39;m gonna realize all

your fantasies about being best friends with 
a kickass pirate captain for some reason!&quot; And

then they have a big musical number together. No, 
they actually do. And you know what? If you&#39;re

not having fun at that point, then there&#39;s 
no reaching your miserable, flinty heart.

Gotta say, all my sphincters clenched when 
that first group of burly toughs showed up,

but when the combat tutorial began, I released 
a sigh of relief from both ends. It&#39;s real-time

combat again. In the long run, the turn-based 
combat in Like a Dragon and Infinite Wealth was

a nice place to visit, but I don&#39;t think this 
franchise should want to live there. It&#39;s just

not the same without disco kung fu mobsters going 
absolute bugfuck on each other with fists, knives,

bicycles, park benches, and the occasional 
salmon. We&#39;re doing the Yakuza 0 thing in

that Majima can switch between two fighting 
styles, which embody the two faces of the

game and helpfully summarizes the clash between 
them. On the one hand, we have Yakuza style,

which Majima defaults to while in the Honolulu 
sandbox, with which we go bugfuck with punches,

kicks, brutal knife stabs, and all that boring, 
old shit, and then we have kickass pirate captain

style he defaults to at all other times, 
where we go bugfuck with dual cutlasses,

grappling hooks, and a magic violin that 
summons ghost sharks. And I couldn&#39;t

even comprehend anyone who&#39;d prefer to use the 
former unless they&#39;re wearing a sophisticated,

face-mounted bomb rigged to go off the 
moment they smile. It&#39;s doubly hard to

understand &#39;cause pirate captain mode basically 
breaks the game once it&#39;s fully upgraded.

I beat the final boss with ease just 
by spamming the grappling hook M. Bison

torpedo dive sword thrust thing that chewed 
up and spat out his health bar like a fucking

Curly Wurly and meant he couldn&#39;t even 
get close enough to criticize my taste

in footwear. But the new thing is ship 
combat, which is about what you&#39;d expect:

all lining up the enemy for cannon barrages 
and waiting for cooldowns but enhanced by the

simple addition of the ability to drift. No, 
it doesn&#39;t make a lot of sense physics-wise,

but after you&#39;ve given the enemy a port broadside, 
immediately doing a handbrake turn and giving

them a starboard one for good measure does feel 
fucking sweet. It&#39;s not the deepest pirate sim;

I wish it&#39;d been one big sandbox ocean rather 
than multiple little ones so we didn&#39;t have to

teleport between them so much like an indecisive 
house-hunting wizard, but it automatically makes

Skull and Bones walk the plank just &#39;cause you 
can walk around on your ship&#39;s deck, handing

out bunches of flowers to your favorite cannon 
operators. And when you take on enemy boss ships,

your entire crew joins you for an on-deck 
free-for-all with their entire crew. And all

your crew are unique characters recruited through 
little mini-quests, and it&#39;s heartening to see the

bikini girl I impressed with my dart-throwing 
skill going bugfuck on a vicious corsair.

And yet, the quest to become king of 
the pirates is still only a side quest,

and being obliged to go back to Honolulu always 
felt like a comedown, with its fetch quests and

its copy-pasted minigames from Infinite Wealth and 
its lovely restaurants. It helped me appreciate

the pirating more the way it&#39;s nice to come home 
and relax after a long day having frantic sex

with birthday cakes, but I continue to find 
Yakuza&#39;s habit of continually churning out

the same shit tiresome because they never address 
the complaints I have with the shit. We&#39;re still

getting forced into random battles with low-level 
dudes long after you outclass them so hard it&#39;s

not even funny, and that&#39;s extended to the ship 
combat now; you can be in the endgame, sailing a

fucking biblical apocalypse with portholes and 
still get harassed by milkmen in rowboats who

keep talking shit right up until you cough and 
obliterate them into matchwood. And once again,

all the really fun bits of a Yakuza story campaign 
are at the end. Fun though it is that we can feed

stray dogs and go-kart and take photos of perverts 
and do endless side stories in which we solve

random people&#39;s personal issues by strategically 
going bugfuck on someone, why do we have to get

passed around between lengthy exposition dialogues 
and repetitive punch-ups for 30 fucking hours

before we get to the boss fight with a giant 
kraken? That&#39;s the shit you lead with, idiots.

I completed all the pirating side 
stuff because that&#39;s where the fun was,

and when I grudgingly got back to the 
plot—which was the usual stuff: conspiracies,

betrayals, get pissed about, villains with 
hearts of gold who do what&#39;s right, i.e.,

go from one smug prick to another and keep 
punching them until we tell you to stop—I

was so massively overpowered it became a dull 
formality, giant kraken fight notwithstanding.

Not for the first time, the final word on a 
Yakuza game is that there&#39;s so much shit in

it there&#39;s bound to be something you like, even 
if you just hang out in your home base playing

the full version of Alex Kidd in Miracle 
World included for some mystifying reason,

but what I liked is tainted by the knowledge 
that there could&#39;ve been so much more of it if

they hadn&#39;t also had to render all the little, 
glittery thongs on the perverts in a minigame I

never had to do or the five varieties of tuna 
steak available at a backstreet restaurant I

didn&#39;t even notice. Think of it. We could&#39;ve been 
playing Alex Kidd in Miracle World on a 300-foot

screen with pixels made of gold dust, wearing all 
the little, glittery thongs a man could desire.
